data.key: Calculation of single deviations.
Calculation of biases.

For a number of points (N), the measured positions are given as xmi , ymi and zmi coordinates depending on the dimension in which the position of the point is measured. A corresponding set of coordinates, xti , yti and zti , are considered to represent the true positions. Formula for 1D positional uncertainty.

For a number of points (N), the measured positions are given as xmi , ymi and zmi coordinates depending on the dimension in which the position of the point is measured. A corresponding set of coordinates, xti , yti and zti , are considered to represent the true positions. Formula for 2D positional uncertainty.

For a number of points (N), the measured positions are given as xmi , ymi and zmi coordinates depending on the dimension in which the position of the point is measured. A criterion for the establishing of correspondence should also be stated (e.g. allowing for correspondence to the closest position, correspondence on vertices or along lines).  The criterion/criteria for finding the corresponding points shall be reported with  the data quality evaluation result. A corresponding set of coordinates, xti , yti and zti , are considered to represent the true positions. Formula for 3D positional uncertainty.
Formula for calculating the mean positional uncertainties of the horizontal absolute or external positions.

For a number of points (N), the measured positions are given as as xmi , ymi and zmi coordinates depending on the dimension in which the position of the point is measured. A corresponding set of coordinates, xti , yti and zti  are considered to represent the true positions. All positional uncertainties above a defined threshold emax are then removed from the set. An outlier (emax) can be considered as blunders or gross errors or use the principle .
Formula for calculation of the mean of the horizontal absolute positions of the remaining number of errors (NR).

For a number of points (N), the measured positions are given as as xmi , ymi and zmi coordinates depending on the dimension in which the position of the point is measured. A corresponding set of coordinates, xti , yti and zti are considered to represent the true positions. 
All positional uncertainties above a defined threshold are then counted as error.

For a number of points (N), the measured positions are given as as xmi , ymi and zmi coordinates depending on the dimension in which the position of the point is measured. A corresponding set of coordinates, xti , yti and zti are considered to represent the true positions. 
All positional uncertainties above a defined threshold are then counted as error.
1D coordinates (e.g. height data). Formula for vector-valued random variable.
1D coordinates (e.g. height data). Formula for the covariance matrix of the vector-valued random variable.
1D coordinates (e.g. height data). Formula for the standard deviation of an element, e.g. x1
1D coordinates (e.g. height data). Formula for the correlation between two elements.
2D coordinates. Formula for the covariance matrix of the vector-valued random variable.
2D coordinates. Formula for the covariance matrix of the vector-valued random variable.

3D coordinates. Formula for the covariance matrix of the vector-valued random variable.

Arbitrary observables.   Formula for the covariance matrix of the vector-valued random variable.
s is the Root Mean Squeare Error and zt is the true values of the observable Z. Formula for the Root Mean Square Error (RMSE) of the observable.
Calculate the absolute error in the vertical dimension at each point.
Calculate the absolute value of the bias.
Calculate the linear standard deviation of measured differences between the tested product and the reference source.
Calculate the linear standard deviation of errors in the reference source.
Calculate the linear standard deviation of errors in the tested product.
Calculate the ratio of the absolute value of the mean error to the standard deviation.
If ratio > 1,4
If ratio ≤ 1,4
Calculate the absolute error in the vertical dimension at each point.
Calculate the mean vertical error.
Calculate the standard deviation of the vertical errors.
Calculate the ratio of the absolute value of the mean error to the standard deviation.
If ratio > 1,4

If ratio ≤ 1,4 then calculate k based on the ratio of the vertical bias to the standard deviation of the heights using a cubic polynomial fit through the tabular values as defined in CRC Handbook of Tables for Probability and Statistics (ISBN 9781315894027).
Compute LE90 for the source.
Compute absolute LE90.
s is the Root Mean Squeare Error and xt and yt are the true values of the observed coordinates X and Y
Calculate the absolute error in the horizontal dimension at each point and each coordinate Xi and Yi
Calculate the mean horizontal error for each coordinate.
Calculate the circular standard deviation of measured differences between the tested product and the reference source.
Calculate the circular standard deviation of errors in the reference source.
Calculate the circular standard deviation of errors in the tested product.
Compute abolute circular error at 90% confidence level of biased data (CMAS).
For i=1..N calculate the absolute error in the horizontal dimension at each point.
Calculate the mean horizontal error
Calculate the standard deviation of the horizontal errors
Calculate the ratio of the absolute value of the mean error to the standard deviation
If ratio > 1,4

If ratio ≤ 1,4 then calculate k, the ratio of the mean to the standard deviation, using a cubic polynomial fit through the tabular values as defined in the CRC Handbook of Tables for Probability and Statistics (ISBN 13: 9780849306921)

Determine all possible point pair combinations.
